dcterms:creator: A. Gallice
I. Monzón
dcterms:description: This dataset models cooperation in social dilemmas through position uncertainty, focusing on how players' contributions are influenced by their knowledge of predecessor groups' contributions.
dcterms:title: Gallice and Monzón (2019) public goods game

dcterms:creator: P. Dal Bó
A. Foster
L. Putterman
dcterms:description: This dataset provides experimental evidence on the effects of democracy on institutions and behavior, highlighting how democratic structures influence cooperation in public goods scenarios.
dcterms:title: Dal Bó et al. (2010)

dcterms:creator: J. Duffy
J. Ochs
dcterms:description: This dataset examines cooperative behavior and the frequency of social interaction, providing insights into how social dynamics affect contributions to public goods.
dcterms:title: Duffy and Ochs (2009)

dcterms:creator: J. Andreoni
P. M. Brown
L. Vesterlund
dcterms:description: This dataset investigates what makes an allocation fair through experimental evidence, contributing to the understanding of fairness in public goods allocation.
dcterms:title: Andreoni et al. (2002)

dcterms:creator: C. Figuieres
D. Masclet
M. Willinger
dcterms:description: This dataset explores the dynamics of leadership and reciprocity in sequential contribution experiments, shedding light on how these factors influence public goods contributions.
dcterms:title: Figuieres et al. (2012)

dcterms:creator: T. Tajika
dcterms:description: This dataset models a dynamic public goods game where players can make a one-off contribution, analyzing the efficiency of contributions in such a setting.
dcterms:title: Tajika (2020)

dcterms:creator: I. Monzón
dcterms:description: This dataset investigates observational learning in large anonymous games, focusing on how players learn from the contributions of others.
dcterms:title: Monzón (2019)

dcterms:creator: I. Monzón
M. Rapp
dcterms:description: This dataset explores observational learning with position uncertainty, analyzing how players' contributions are influenced by their knowledge of others' actions.
dcterms:title: Monzón and Rapp (2014)
